This is a classic scenario-based question that tests your ability to analyze and make inferences based on the given information. In this case, you are asked to choose between two options (A and B) based on the description of the male recipient's email habits.

The correct answer is neither A nor B, as there is no information provided in the passage to suggest either option is more likely to occur. The passage simply states that the male recipient's email inbox is full of junk emails, without providing any additional details or context. Therefore, it is impossible to make an informed decision about which option is more likely to happen.

To solve this type of question, always read the passage carefully and look for clues that can help you make an educated guess. In this case, since there is no information provided to support either option, the best answer is "neither."

This is a classic example of the "false dilemma" fallacy. The passage presents two options as if they are the only possibilities when in fact there may be other alternatives. In reality, it's possible that both countries may have developed nuclear weapons and also negotiated agreements to reduce tensions between them. Therefore, neither option A nor B can be said to be more likely to occur based on the given information.

This is a classic lateral thinking puzzle. The answer is that neither option A nor B is more likely to happen. The reason is that the father's reaction is not determined by his discovery of the son's lies, but rather by the son's admission of the truth. If the son admits the truth, the father may react differently than if he discovers the lie.
